title.narrative: Stöd till HIPS - startegisk utvecklingsplan för 2015/2016
Support to the Heritage Institute for Policy Studies

description.narrative:
The Heritage Institute for Policy Studies (HIPS) har ansökt om stöd från Sida på totalt MSEK 4 för genomförandet av sin strategiska plan "HIPS strategic development plan 2015-2016" i Somalia under perioden 1 oktober 2015 till 31 December 2016.
Insatsen syftar dels till att stärka institutet i sin roll som en nationell think tank och dess kapacitet att kunna påverka policybeslut genom att bland annat producera "policy briefs" baserat på dess tematiska forksknings- och påverkansprogram. Detta stöd inbegriper därför i) stärkandet av den institutionella strukturen, ii) stärkt kapacitet för resursmobilisering, iii) ökad personalkapacitet, iv) stärkt finansiell administrativ kapacitet. Insatsen syftar också till att stödja implementeringen av HIPS strategiska utvecklingsplan 2015 som inkluderar tematiska forsknings- och påverkansprogram . HIPS kommer även att genomföra en trendanalys av Sveriges stöd till Somalia.

The Heritage Institute for Policy Studies (HIPS) has applied to Sida for funding of 4 million SEK to carry out the ''HIPS strategic development plan 2015-2016'' in Somalia during the period 1 October 2015 to 31 December 2016.
The intervention aims at strengthening HIPS which is a national policy institute to be able to play their role more effectively as a think tank influencing policy decisions on Somalia by producing policy briefs from their thematic research programs and outreach and impact programs. Therefore the support aims at i) institutional structure strengthening, ii) increased capacity for resource mobilization, iii) increased human resource capacity, iv) increased financial administration capacity. The intervention also aims at supporting the implementation of the HIPS strategic development plan 2015 which includes thematic research programs and outreach and impact programs. The Research, Analysis and Development Evaluations (RAADE), with is a unit within HIPS will also conduct a trend analysis of Swedish support in Somalia.

description.narrative: General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: In 2015, the Heritage Institute for Policy Studies (HIPS) applied for funding from SIDA to support the core activities of the institute. HIPS proposed, in the form of a log frame and work plan, the activities to be undertaken by the organization and it also outlined how this will contribute to the vision and objectives of the institute as it implements its research agenda in Somalia. The application for funding was approved in October 2015 and a formal agreement was signed between HIPS and SIDA. The support has the dual objectives of supporting the institute’s organizational growth and development and the research agenda for 2016. In the first two quarters of implementation, HIPS managed to develop key manuals, namely finance manual, procurement and travel policies and secured the approval of the board. A human resource manual was developed and shared with the board for review and approval (the approval has been since been received after the reporting period). A deputy director and a researcher – were hired as part of the institutional building process and the institute is in the final stages of recruiting a senior researcher. Both HIPS and RAADE have made significant progress towards achieving their core mandates. HIPS published reports on Turkey’s aid in Somalia, a report on AMISOM’s exit challenges, role of the Arab League in Somalia and the citizens' view on the selection of the next Somali parliament. . On the other hand, both HIPS and Raade took part in call for proposals for various activities such as DfID's Somalia Monitoring Program (SMP) II, EU's Third Party Monitoring and Evaluation (TPME) and various World Bank calls for proposal. This is a testimony of the organization's potential to expand and achieve long term sustainability if core funding is secured. In March, the Research, Analysis And development Evaluations (RAADE) Group conducted 12 focus group discussions across 12 locations in Somalia (6 urban and 6 rural locations) to understand the perceptions of Somalis on social, economic and political situation in the country. The first quarter report has been finalized following feedback from SIDA and a more in-depth analysis by the research team. HIPS has also reactivated its Forum for Ideas roundtable discussions and plans to organize, in December, a National Forum for Ideas intended to bring together the most influential Somalis from all segments / professions so they could compare notes on vital issues that concern all Somalis from youth radicalization to the role of the business community on peace and state building strategies.
